Name: Radiation: What It Is, What You Need to Know

ReviewList.Text: This book puts the radiation health risk of nuclear power in perspective. It points out that the the risks of climate change from fosil fuel burning out weigh the potential  health risks associated with nuclear power. This is a sorely needed message in that the public thinks that nuclear power is a thousand times more dangerous than coal burning but the data shows that the oposite is in fact the reality.

This was a very detailed account of various radiological subjects. The authors have clearly defined many aspects of radiation through the ages. The discussions within these pages takes the myths/horrors that I had once held and gave me a better sense of understanding, less fear. I would recommend this read to anyone with preconceived notions about nuclear power etc... this book will educate and hopefully ease ones mind about the use/exposure to radiation.

Great read. Excellent info on Radiation. Provides excellent statistics and facts from WWII bombings to Pacific nuclear tests. Provides an in-depth easy to read text. No previous scientific knowledge is needed to understand text material. Authors couldn't have been more enthusiastic about writing this book. Anyone interested in science related careers or perhaps even a quick understanding of what radiation is, will find this helpful. "Coffee" table style book, packed with enough information. Information includes, what is radiation?, radiation history, types of radiation, should we fear or worship radiation? how radiation is used (past and tense), where radiation technology and understanding is going. Like stated above, quick mediocre "coffee" table kind of read. Up-to-date book, written after the Fukishima disaster. Modern applications included.

It is a pleasure to find this book relevant and factual. It is written by a physician with excellent credentials and experience in the field of leukemia. By first addressing the radiation effects of the survivors of the Hiroshima / Nagasaki atomic bombs studied in a joint USA-Japanese study still ongoing, the book shows how little were the effects and why. After further explanations based on Chernobyl and Three Mile Island, the book addresses the survivors of the Fukushima massive tsunami waves to explain ( page 132) why “any impact of radiation released at Fukushima is extremely unlikely”. This was confirmed upon completion on April 2, 2014 by the United Nations’ study of Fukushima by their international technical group, originally formed to study the atomic bomb effects. AND THE BOOK IS READABLE !!

Radiation could be dangerous and non-dangerous on planet. It could be use either good way or bad, and sometimes human needs radiation to cure disease. Through this "Radiation:What It Is, What You Need to Know" readers can really understand that this marital could be harmful.  Human who are living in their country and have to worry about what if radiation explode, and how do they deal with it.  Readers will follow writer's story-line  to understands how does radiation works, and analyze two sides of good and bad of chemical reaction.

Radiation provides an understanding of concepts that everyone one will benefit from.  It highlights dangers, describes benefits, but most importantly provides knowledge that mitigates irrational, unwarranted fears.

Provides good insights on the nature of Radiation, types of radioactivity, and sources of radioactivity.  It outlines the facts about radioactivity and the misconceptions about radioactivity many people have.  Easy to read and understand, and well worth the price.

I am surprised at the amount of sterling reviews. I found the book tedious and often not plausible. See this from the EPA which disagrees strongly with the authors about the health effects of radiation.  http://www.epa.gov/radiation/understand/health_effects.html
The authors did a very good job in correctly describing radiation, it's history,and its effects (both positive and negative).  The book is factual and well written.
I am entirely pleased with the presentation and depth of the information offered in this book! Very informative while easy to read. Answered all my questions.
I knew what to expect when I went for my treatments but I was told by my doctor this book is 5 years behind radiation treatments when it was published.

From the casual reader, to the scientist looking for a comprehensive discussion of the topic of radiation, this book delivers on all fronts. Well written, thoughtful and immensely interesting, this book is a must read for anyone who has questions about radiation and its implications in everyday life. In a world ever more confronted with global warming, natural disasters and terrorism, I found that this book gave straight forward answers to the way that radiation and nuclear power fits into these callenges facing humanity. I recommend this book, and guarantee that you won't be disappointed!
A balanced view and easy to understand for the lay person.

This complex subject becomes more complex the more you read.  The answers are many and fuzzy since one cannot test effects of radiation on humans, but instead has to rely on exposure studies from WWII, Chernobyl and Fukishima.  While the book did appear to cover what is known, it would have benefitted greatly from shorter more numerous chapters so the reader could have a stopping point to digest the material.  I did finally learn something I wanted to know for a long time --  How long will it take for nuclear radiation to go away?  --  Plutonium needs 240,000 years to break down completely.
